Linearity problem for non-abelian tensor products

Valeriy G. Bardakov ,  Andrei V. Lavrenov  and  Mikhail V. Neshchadim Sobolev Institute of Mathematics, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia, Novosibirsk State University, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia, Novosibirsk State Agrarian University, Dobrolyubova street, 160, Novosibirsk, 630039, Russia, bardakov@math.nsc.ru Saint-Petersburg State University, University Embankment, 7–9, Saint-Petersburg, 199034, Russia, A.V.Lavrenov@gmail.com Sobolev Institute of Mathematics and Novosibirsk State University, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia, neshch@math.nsc.ru
Abstract.

In this paper we give an example of a linear group such that its tensor square is not linear. Also, we formulate some sufficient conditions for the linearity of non-abelian tensor products G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H and tensor squares G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G. Using these results we prove that tensor squares of some groups with one relation and some knot groups are linear. We prove that the Peiffer square of a finitely generated linear group is linear. At the end we construct faithful linear representations for the non-abelian tensor square of a free group and free nilpotent group.

Key words and phrases:
non-abelian tensor product; linear group; faithful linear representation
2010 Mathematics Subject Classification:
Primary 20E25; Secondary 20G20, 20E05

1. Introduction

R. Brown and J.-L. Loday [8, 9] introduced the non-abelian tensor product G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H for a pair of groups G𝐺G and H𝐻H following works of Miller [5], and Lue [7]. They showed that the third homotopy group of the suspension of an Eilenberg-MacLane space K​(G,1)𝐾𝐺1K(G,1) satisfies

π3​S​K​(G,1)≅J2​(G),subscript𝜋3𝑆𝐾𝐺1subscript𝐽2𝐺\pi_{3}SK(G,1)\cong J_{2}(G),

where J2​(G)subscript𝐽2𝐺J_{2}(G) is the kernel of the derived map κ:G⊗G⟶G′:𝜅⟶tensor-product𝐺𝐺superscript𝐺′\kappa:G\otimes G\longrightarrow G^{\prime}, g⊗h↦[g,h]=g−1​h−1​g​hmaps-totensor-product𝑔ℎ𝑔ℎsuperscript𝑔1superscriptℎ1𝑔ℎg\otimes h\mapsto[g,h]=g^{-1}h^{-1}gh. Hence there exists the short exact sequence

0⟶π3​S​K​(G,1)⟶G⊗G⟶G′⟶1.⟶0subscript𝜋3𝑆𝐾𝐺1⟶tensor-product𝐺𝐺⟶superscript𝐺′⟶10\longrightarrow\pi_{3}SK(G,1)\longrightarrow G\otimes G\longrightarrow G^{\prime}\longrightarrow 1.

Also, the non-abelian tensor product is used to describe the third relative homotopy group of a triad as a non-abelian tensor product of the second homotopy groups of appropriate subspaces. More specifically, let a C​W𝐶𝑊CW-complex X𝑋X be the union X=A∪B𝑋𝐴𝐵X=A\cup B of two path-connected C​W𝐶𝑊CW-subspaces A𝐴A and B𝐵B whose intersection C=A∩B𝐶𝐴𝐵C=A\cap B is path-connected. If the canonical homomorphisms π1​(C)⟶π1​(A)⟶subscript𝜋1𝐶subscript𝜋1𝐴\pi_{1}(C)\longrightarrow\pi_{1}(A), π1​(C)⟶π1​(B)⟶subscript𝜋1𝐶subscript𝜋1𝐵\pi_{1}(C)\longrightarrow\pi_{1}(B) are surjective, then, according to [8],

π3​(X,A,B)≅π2​(A,C)⊗π2​(B,C),subscript𝜋3𝑋𝐴𝐵tensor-productsubscript𝜋2𝐴𝐶subscript𝜋2𝐵𝐶\pi_{3}(X,A,B)\cong\pi_{2}(A,C)\otimes\pi_{2}(B,C),

where the groups π2​(A,C)subscript𝜋2𝐴𝐶\pi_{2}(A,C) and π2​(B,C)subscript𝜋2𝐵𝐶\pi_{2}(B,C) act on one another via π1​(C)subscript𝜋1𝐶\pi_{1}(C).

The investigation of the non-abelian tensor product from a group theoretical point of view started with a paper by Brown, Johnson, and Robertson [15]. They compute the non-abelian tensor square of all non-abelian groups of order up to 30 using Tietze transformations.

One of the topics of research on the non-abelian tensor products has been to determine which group properties are preserved by non-abelian tensor products. By using homological arguments, Ellis [10] showed that if G𝐺G and H𝐻H are finite groups, then G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H is also finite. Visscher [12] proved that if G𝐺G, H𝐻H are solvable (nilpotent), then G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H is solvable (nilpotent) and gives a bound on the nilpotency class of G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H. In [17] it was proved that the tensor product of groups of nilpotency class at most n𝑛n is a group of nilpotency class at most n𝑛n, thereby improving the bound given by Visscher. For other results in this direction see the survey of Nakaoka [13].

In this paper we study the linearity problem for non-abelian tensor products. Let n𝑛n be a positive integer and let P𝑃P be a field. A group G𝐺G is said to be linear of degree n𝑛n over P𝑃P if it is isomorphic with a subgroup of G​Ln​(P)𝐺subscript𝐿𝑛𝑃GL_{n}(P), the group of all n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n non-singular matrices over P𝑃P or, equivalently, if it is isomorphic with a group of invertible linear transformations of a vector space of dimension n𝑛n over P𝑃P (see [19]). We study the following

Question 1.

Let G𝐺G and H𝐻H be linear groups. Are the groups G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H, G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G linear?

We show that in general the answer is negative. More accurately, we prove that the tensor square S​Ln​(ℚ)⊗S​Ln​(ℚ)tensor-product𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚ𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚSL_{n}(\mathbb{Q})\otimes SL_{n}(\mathbb{Q}) of the special linear group S​Ln​(ℚ)𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚSL_{n}(\mathbb{Q}) over the field of rational numbers is not linear for n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3. On the other side we formulate some sufficient conditions under which the groups G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H, G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G are linear. Using these conditions, we prove that the non-abelian tensor squares of some groups with one defining relation and groups of fibered knots are linear. If G𝐺G is a finitely generated free group or finitely generated free nilpotent group, then we construct concrete faithful linear representations for G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G.

The non-abelian tensor square G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G is connected to other group constructions: exterior tensor square G∧G𝐺𝐺G\wedge G and Peiffert square G⋈G⋈𝐺𝐺G\bowtie G. We prove that if G𝐺G is finitely generated, then G⋈G⋈𝐺𝐺G\bowtie G is linear.

We note that the following problems are still open.

Problem 1.

1) Let G𝐺G be a finitely generated linear group. Is the group G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G linear?

2) Let G𝐺G be a linear group. Is the group G⋈G⋈𝐺𝐺G\bowtie G linear?

Also we thank to J. O. Button and O. V. Bryukhanov for examples of linear groups with non-linear abelization (see section 5). The present work was supported by Russian Science Foundation (project No. 16-41-02006).

2. Preliminaries

In this paper we shall use the following notations. For elements x𝑥x, y𝑦y in a group G𝐺G, the conjugation of x𝑥x by y𝑦y is xy=y−1​x​ysuperscript𝑥𝑦superscript𝑦1𝑥𝑦x^{y}=y^{-1}xy; and the commutator of x𝑥x and y𝑦y is [x,y]=x−1​xy=x−1​y−1​x​y𝑥𝑦superscript𝑥1superscript𝑥𝑦superscript𝑥1superscript𝑦1𝑥𝑦[x,y]=x^{-1}x^{y}=x^{-1}y^{-1}xy. We write G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} for the derived subgroup of G𝐺G, Ga​bsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏G^{ab} for the abelianized group G/G′𝐺superscript𝐺′G/G^{\prime}.

Recall the definition of the non-abelian tensor product G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H of groups G𝐺G and H𝐻H (see [8, 9]). This tensor product is defined for any pair of groups G𝐺G and H𝐻H where each one acts on the other (on the right)

G×H⟶G,(g,h)↦gh;H×G⟶H,(h,g)↦hgformulae-sequence⟶𝐺𝐻𝐺formulae-sequencemaps-to𝑔ℎsuperscript𝑔ℎformulae-sequence⟶𝐻𝐺𝐻maps-toℎ𝑔superscriptℎ𝑔G\times H\longrightarrow G,~{}~{}(g,h)\mapsto g^{h};~{}~{}~{}H\times G\longrightarrow H,~{}~{}(h,g)\mapsto h^{g}

and on itself by conjugation, in such a way that for all g,g1∈G𝑔subscript𝑔1𝐺g,g_{1}\in G and h,h1∈H,ℎsubscriptℎ1𝐻h,h_{1}\in H,

g(hg1)=((gg1−1)h)g1​and​h(gh1)=((hh1−1)g)h1.superscript𝑔superscriptℎsubscript𝑔1superscriptsuperscriptsuperscript𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑔11ℎsubscript𝑔1andsuperscriptℎsuperscript𝑔subscriptℎ1superscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptℎsuperscriptsubscriptℎ11𝑔subscriptℎ1g^{(h^{g_{1}})}=\left(\left(g^{g_{1}^{-1}}\right)^{h}\right)^{g_{1}}~{}~{}\mbox{and}~{}~{}h^{(g^{h_{1}})}=\left(\left(h^{h_{1}^{-1}}\right)^{g}\right)^{h_{1}}.

In this situation we say that G𝐺G and H𝐻H act compatibly on each other. The non-abelian tensor product G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H is the group generated by all symbols g⊗htensor-product𝑔ℎg\otimes h, g∈G𝑔𝐺g\in G, h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in H, subject to the relations

g​g1⊗h=(gg1⊗hg1)​(g1⊗h)​and​g⊗h​h1=(g⊗h1)​(gh1⊗hh1)tensor-product𝑔subscript𝑔1ℎtensor-producttensor-productsuperscript𝑔subscript𝑔1superscriptℎsubscript𝑔1tensor-productsubscript𝑔1ℎand𝑔ℎsubscriptℎ1tensor-product𝑔subscriptℎ1tensor-productsuperscript𝑔subscriptℎ1superscriptℎsubscriptℎ1gg_{1}\otimes h=(g^{g_{1}}\otimes h^{g_{1}})(g_{1}\otimes h)~{}\mbox{and}~{}~{}g\otimes hh_{1}=(g\otimes h_{1})(g^{h_{1}}\otimes h^{h_{1}})

for all g,g1∈G𝑔subscript𝑔1𝐺g,g_{1}\in G, h,h1∈Hℎsubscriptℎ1𝐻h,h_{1}\in H.

In particular, as the conjugation action of a group G𝐺G on itself is compatible, then the tensor square G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G of a group G𝐺G may always be defined. Also, the tensor product G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H is defined if G𝐺G and H𝐻H are two normal subgroups of some group M𝑀M and actions are conjugations in M𝑀M.

3. Linearity problem

In this section we will use a result of Malcev [19] (see also [20, Chapter 2]) on the linearity of abelian groups. To formulate it recall some definitions. If G𝐺G is any group τ​(G)𝜏𝐺\tau(G) is the subgroup of G𝐺G generated by all the periodic normal subgroups of G𝐺G; that is τ​(G)𝜏𝐺\tau(G) is the maximum periodic normal subgroup of G𝐺G. G𝐺G has finite rank at most n𝑛n if every finite subset of G𝐺G is contained in an n𝑛n-generator subgroup of G𝐺G. If G𝐺G is abelian and periodic then G𝐺G has finite rank at most n𝑛n if and only if for each prime p𝑝p the Sylow p𝑝p-subgroup of G𝐺G is a direct product of at most n𝑛n cyclic and Prüfer p𝑝p-groups (a Prüfer p𝑝p-group is a ℂp∞subscriptℂsuperscript𝑝\mathbb{C}_{p^{\infty}}-group). If π𝜋\pi is any set of primes and G𝐺G is a group with a unique maximal π𝜋\pi-subgroup we denote this maximal π𝜋\pi-subgroup by Gπsubscript𝐺𝜋G_{\pi}.

Malcev proved:

i) An abelian group A𝐴A has a faithful representation of degree n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 over some field of characteristic zero if and only if τ​(G)𝜏𝐺\tau(G) has rank at most n𝑛n.

ii) An abelian group A𝐴A has a faithful representation of degree n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 over some field of characteristic p>0𝑝0p>0 if and only if τ​(G)p′𝜏subscript𝐺superscript𝑝′\tau(G)_{p^{\prime}} (here p′superscript𝑝′p^{\prime} denotes all primes except p𝑝p) has finite rank r𝑟r and τ​(A)p𝜏subscript𝐴𝑝\tau(A)_{p} has finite exponent pesuperscript𝑝𝑒p^{e} satisfying

pe−1+max⁡{1,r}<n+1.superscript𝑝𝑒11𝑟𝑛1p^{e-1}+\max\{1,r\}<n+1.

We are ready to prove the following

Proposition 3.1.

There is a linear group G𝐺G such that G⊗G=G∧Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺𝐺𝐺G\otimes G=G\wedge G is not linear.

Proof.

For a perfect group G=G′𝐺superscript𝐺′G=G^{\prime} it follows from the main diagram (see section 2) that G⊗G=G∧Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺𝐺𝐺G\otimes G=G\wedge G and the sequence

0⟶H2​(G,ℤ)⟶G⊗G⟶G⟶0⟶0subscript𝐻2𝐺ℤ⟶tensor-product𝐺𝐺⟶𝐺⟶00\longrightarrow H_{2}(G,\,\mathbb{Z})\longrightarrow G\otimes G\longrightarrow G\longrightarrow 0

is exact.

For n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3 the group S​Ln​(ℚ)𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚSL_{n}(\mathbb{Q}) is perfect and its second homology group coincides with the K2subscriptK2\mathrm{K}_{2}-group of the field ℚℚ\mathbb{Q},

H2​(S​Ln​(ℚ),ℤ)=K2​(ℚ),subscript𝐻2𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚℤsubscriptK2ℚH_{2}(SL_{n}(\mathbb{Q}),\,\mathbb{Z})=\mathrm{K}_{2}(\mathbb{Q}),

see [6, Corollary 11.2].

Next,

K2​(ℚ)={±1}×∏p​ odd prime(ℤ/p)×subscriptK2ℚplus-or-minus1subscriptproduct𝑝 odd primesuperscriptℤ𝑝\mathrm{K}_{2}(\mathbb{Q})=\{\pm 1\}\times\prod\limits_{p\text{ odd prime}}(\mathbb{Z}/p)^{\times}

by [6, Theorem 11.6], so that K2​(ℚ)subscriptK2ℚ\mathrm{K}_{2}(\mathbb{Q}) contains an abelian 2-group of infinite rank and unbounded exponent. Using Maltsev’s criterion we conclude that such a group can not be linear. Therefore the group

S​Ln​(ℚ)⊗S​Ln​(ℚ)=S​Ln​(ℚ)∧S​Ln​(ℚ)tensor-product𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚ𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚ𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚ𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚSL_{n}(\mathbb{Q})\otimes SL_{n}(\mathbb{Q})=SL_{n}(\mathbb{Q})\wedge SL_{n}(\mathbb{Q})

is not linear as well. ∎

To study the linearity problem for the non-abelian tensor product we can use a presentation of a tensor product as a central extension (see, for example, [17].) The derivative subgroup of G𝐺G by H𝐻H is defined to be the following subgroup

DH​(G)=[G,H]=⟨g−1​gh|g∈G,h∈H⟩.subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺𝐺𝐻inner-productsuperscript𝑔1superscript𝑔ℎformulae-sequence𝑔𝐺ℎ𝐻D_{H}(G)=[G,H]=\langle g^{-1}g^{h}~{}|~{}g\in G,h\in H\rangle.

The map κ:G⊗H⟶DH​(G):𝜅⟶tensor-product𝐺𝐻subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺\kappa:G\otimes H\longrightarrow D_{H}(G) defined by κ​(g⊗h)=g−1​gh𝜅tensor-product𝑔ℎsuperscript𝑔1superscript𝑔ℎ\kappa(g\otimes h)=g^{-1}g^{h} is a homomorphism, its kernel is the central subgroup of G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H and G𝐺G acts on G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H by the rule (g⊗h)x=gx⊗hxsuperscripttensor-product𝑔ℎ𝑥tensor-productsuperscript𝑔𝑥superscriptℎ𝑥(g\otimes h)^{x}=g^{x}\otimes h^{x}, x∈G𝑥𝐺x\in G. There exists the short exact sequence

1⟶A⟶G⊗H⟶DH​(G)⟶1.⟶1𝐴⟶tensor-product𝐺𝐻⟶subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺⟶11\longrightarrow A\longrightarrow G\otimes H\longrightarrow D_{H}(G)\longrightarrow 1.

In this case A𝐴A can be viewed as a ℤ​[DH​(G)]ℤdelimited-[]subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺\mathbb{Z}[D_{H}(G)]-module via conjugation in G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H, i. e. under the action induced by setting

a⋅g=x−1​a​x,a∈A,x∈G⊗H,κ​(x)=g.formulae-sequence⋅𝑎𝑔superscript𝑥1𝑎𝑥formulae-sequence𝑎𝐴formulae-sequence𝑥tensor-product𝐺𝐻𝜅𝑥𝑔a\cdot g=x^{-1}ax,~{}~{}a\in A,x\in G\otimes H,\kappa(x)=g.

We can formulate some sufficient conditions for the linearity of G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H. It is well known that the tensor product G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H with trivial actions is isomorphic to the abelian tensor product Ga​b⊗ℤHa​bsubscripttensor-productℤsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏superscript𝐻𝑎𝑏G^{ab}\otimes_{\mathbb{Z}}H^{ab}. Hence, in this case the question on the linearity of G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H is equivalent to the question on the linearity of the abelian tensor product and the answer follows from the Malcev theorem.

Further we will assume that the action of G𝐺G on H𝐻H or the action of H𝐻H on G𝐺G is non-trivial. We have the following short exact sequence

(1)1 0⟶A⟶G⊗H⟶DH​(G)⟶1.⟶0𝐴⟶tensor-product𝐺𝐻⟶subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺⟶10\longrightarrow A\longrightarrow G\otimes H\longrightarrow D_{H}(G)\longrightarrow 1.

Note that A𝐴A is the kernel of the natural map G⊗H⟶DH​(G)⟶tensor-product𝐺𝐻subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺G\otimes H\longrightarrow D_{H}(G), g⊗h⟶g−1​gh⟶tensor-product𝑔ℎsuperscript𝑔1superscript𝑔ℎg\otimes h\longrightarrow g^{-1}g^{h}, g∈G𝑔𝐺g\in G, h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in H, and is a central subgroup of G⊗Htensor-product𝐺𝐻G\otimes H.

Proposition 3.2.

Let the following conditions hold

1) A𝐴A, DH​(G)subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺D_{H}(G) are linear groups;

2) H2​(DH​(G),A)=0superscript𝐻2subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺𝐴0H^{2}(D_{H}(G),A)=0, in particular, this condition holds if A𝐴A is divisible or DH​(G)subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺D_{H}(G) is a free group.

Then G⊗H=A×DH​(G)tensor-product𝐺𝐻𝐴subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺G\otimes H=A\times D_{H}(G) is the direct product and is a linear group.

Proof.

It is well known that if H2​(DH​(G),A)=0superscript𝐻2subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺𝐴0H^{2}(D_{H}(G),A)=0, then the sequence

0⟶A⟶G⊗H⟶DH​(G)⟶1,⟶0𝐴⟶tensor-product𝐺𝐻⟶subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺⟶10\longrightarrow A\longrightarrow G\otimes H\longrightarrow D_{H}(G)\longrightarrow 1,

splits. In particular, this condition holds if A𝐴A is divisible or DH​(G)subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺D_{H}(G) is a free group.

Since A𝐴A is a central subgroup, then G⊗H≅A×DH​(G)tensor-product𝐺𝐻𝐴subscript𝐷𝐻𝐺G\otimes H\cong A\times D_{H}(G) and is a linear group as a direct product of linear groups.

∎

The main problem in the use of this theorem is the description of the central subgroup A𝐴A. For the tensor square we can use another approach.

Let us formulate some sufficient conditions under which G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G is a direct product of the commutator subgroup G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} and the Whitehead group Γ​(Ga​b)Γsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏\Gamma(G^{ab}).

Theorem 3.3.

Let H2​(G)=H3​(G)=H2​(G′)=0subscript𝐻2𝐺subscript𝐻3𝐺subscript𝐻2superscript𝐺′0H_{2}(G)=H_{3}(G)=H_{2}(G^{\prime})=0 and one of the following conditions hold

Then

G⊗G≅Γ​(Ga​b)×G′.tensor-product𝐺𝐺Γsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏superscript𝐺′G\otimes G\cong\Gamma(G^{ab})\times G^{\prime}.

If moreover G𝐺G is finitely generated and G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} is linear, then G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G is linear.

Proof.

Since, H2​(G)=H3​(G)=0subscript𝐻2𝐺subscript𝐻3𝐺0H_{2}(G)=H_{3}(G)=0, then the main diagram has the form

00↓↓0→Γ​(Ga​b)→ψJ2​(G)→0→0∥↓↓0→Γ​(Ga​b)→ψG⊗G→G∧G→1↓↓G′=G′↓↓11missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression0missing-subexpression0missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression↓missing-subexpression↓missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression0→Γsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏superscript→𝜓subscript𝐽2𝐺→0→0missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionparallel-tomissing-subexpression↓missing-subexpression↓missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression0→Γsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏superscript→𝜓tensor-product𝐺𝐺→𝐺𝐺→1missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression↓missing-subexpression↓missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionsuperscript𝐺′superscript𝐺′missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression↓missing-subexpression↓missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression1missing-subexpression1missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression\begin{array}[]{ccccccccc}&&&&0&&0&&\\ &&&&\downarrow&&\downarrow&&\\ 0&\rightarrow&\Gamma(G^{ab})&\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\psi}}{{\rightarrow}}&J_{2}(G)&\rightarrow&0&\rightarrow&0\\ &&\shortparallel&&\downarrow&&\downarrow&&\\ 0&\rightarrow&\Gamma(G^{ab})&\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\psi}}{{\rightarrow}}&G\otimes G&\rightarrow&G\wedge G&\rightarrow&1\\ &&&&\downarrow&&\downarrow&&\\ &&&&G^{\prime}&=&G^{\prime}&&\\ &&&&\downarrow&&\downarrow&&\\ &&&&1&&1&&\\ \end{array}

As consequence we get the following result

Corollary 3.4.

[2] Let Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n} be a free group of rank n𝑛n. Then

Fn⊗Fn≅ℤn​(n+1)/2×(Fn)′.tensor-productsubscript𝐹𝑛subscript𝐹𝑛superscriptℤ𝑛𝑛12superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛′F_{n}\otimes F_{n}\cong\mathbb{Z}^{n(n+1)/2}\times(F_{n})^{\prime}.

4. Groups with one defining relation and knot groups

Let G𝐺G be a group with one defining relation:

G=⟨X∥r=1⟩,𝐺inner-product𝑋𝑟1G=\left\langle\,X\,\|\,r=1\,\right\rangle,

where r∉F′𝑟superscript𝐹′r\not\in F^{\prime}, F=⟨X⟩𝐹delimited-⟨⟩𝑋F=\left\langle\,X\,\right\rangle. Then Hk​(G)=0subscript𝐻𝑘𝐺0H_{k}(G)=0, k≥2𝑘2k\geq 2 (see [3, p. 49]). Hence, there exists the following short exact sequence:

0⟶Γ​(Ga​b)⟶G⊗G⟶G′⟶1.⟶0Γsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏⟶tensor-product𝐺𝐺⟶superscript𝐺′⟶10\longrightarrow\Gamma(G^{ab})\longrightarrow G\otimes G\longrightarrow G^{\prime}\longrightarrow 1.

If Ga​bsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏G^{ab} does not have torsion, then Ga​bsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏G^{ab} is a free abelian group and Γ​(Ga​b)Γsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏\Gamma(G^{ab}) is a free abelian group. Then, if H2​(G′)=0superscript𝐻2superscript𝐺′0H^{2}(G^{\prime})=0, then H2​(G′,Γ​(Ga​b))=0superscript𝐻2superscript𝐺′Γsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏0H^{2}(G^{\prime},\Gamma(G^{ab}))=0, which follows from the decomposition

Hk​(S,A⊕B)=Hk​(S,A)⊕Hk​(S,B)superscript𝐻𝑘𝑆direct-sum𝐴𝐵direct-sumsuperscript𝐻𝑘𝑆𝐴superscript𝐻𝑘𝑆𝐵H^{k}(S,A\oplus B)=H^{k}(S,A)\oplus H^{k}(S,B)

for every group S𝑆S and all S𝑆S-modules A𝐴A and B𝐵B.

From Theorem 3.3 follows

Proposition 4.1.

Let G𝐺G be a group with one defining relation:

G=⟨X∥r=1⟩,𝐺inner-product𝑋𝑟1G=\left\langle\,X\,\|\,r=1\,\right\rangle,

where r∉F′𝑟superscript𝐹′r\not\in F^{\prime}, F=⟨X⟩𝐹delimited-⟨⟩𝑋F=\left\langle\,X\,\right\rangle such that H2​(G′)=0superscript𝐻2superscript𝐺′0H^{2}(G^{\prime})=0. If one from the following conditions hold:

1) Ga​bsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏G^{ab} does not have torsion;

2) G′/G′′superscript𝐺′superscript𝐺′′G^{\prime}/G^{\prime\prime} is a free abelian group.

Then G⊗G=Γ​(Ga​b)×G′tensor-product𝐺𝐺Γsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏superscript𝐺′G\otimes G=\Gamma(G^{ab})\times G^{\prime}. If moreover G𝐺G is finitely generated and G𝐺G is linear, then G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G is linear.

It is well known that if K𝐾K is a tame knot in 3-sphere 𝕊3superscript𝕊3\mathbb{S}^{3} and GK=π1​(𝕊3∖K)subscript𝐺𝐾subscript𝜋1superscript𝕊3𝐾G_{K}=\pi_{1}(\mathbb{S}^{3}\setminus K) its group, then Hn​(GK)=0subscript𝐻𝑛subscript𝐺𝐾0H_{n}(G_{K})=0 for n>1𝑛1n>1 (see, for example [18, p. 5]). Recall that a knot K𝐾K is called fibered if there is a 1-parameter family Ftsubscript𝐹𝑡F_{t} of Seifert surfaces for K𝐾K, where the parameter t𝑡t runs through the points of the unit circle S1superscript𝑆1S^{1}, such that if s𝑠s is not equal to t𝑡t then the intersection of Fssubscript𝐹𝑠F_{s} and Ftsubscript𝐹𝑡F_{t} is exactly K𝐾K. The commutator subgroup GK′superscriptsubscript𝐺𝐾′G_{K}^{\prime} for the fibered knot K𝐾K is a free group of finite rank [14] and GKsubscript𝐺𝐾G_{K} is linear [1].

Proposition 4.2.

Let K𝐾K be a tame fibered knot in 3-sphere 𝕊3superscript𝕊3\mathbb{S}^{3}, then GK⊗GK=GK′×ℤtensor-productsubscript𝐺𝐾subscript𝐺𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐺𝐾′ℤG_{K}\otimes G_{K}=G_{K}^{\prime}\times\mathbb{Z} and has a faithful linear representation into G​L2​(ℤ​[t,t−1])𝐺subscript𝐿2ℤ𝑡superscript𝑡1GL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}[t,t^{-1}]).

Proof.

It is well known that GKa​b=ℤsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝐾𝑎𝑏ℤG_{K}^{ab}=\mathbb{Z} and then Γ​(GKa​b)=ℤΓsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝐾𝑎𝑏ℤ\Gamma(G_{K}^{ab})=\mathbb{Z}. From Theorem 3.3 it follows that GK⊗GK=ℤ×GK′tensor-productsubscript𝐺𝐾subscript𝐺𝐾ℤsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝐾′G_{K}\otimes G_{K}=\mathbb{Z}\times G_{K}^{\prime}.

To construct a linear representation, use the fact that GK′superscriptsubscript𝐺𝐾′G_{K}^{\prime} is a free group of finite rank and by Sanov’s theorem [11, Chapter 5] it has a faithful linear representation into S​L2​(ℤ)≤G​L2​(ℤ​[t,t−1])𝑆subscript𝐿2ℤ𝐺subscript𝐿2ℤ𝑡superscript𝑡1SL_{2}(\mathbb{Z})\leq GL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}[t,t^{-1}]). Define a linear representation of GKa​b=ℤ=⟨γ⟩superscriptsubscript𝐺𝐾𝑎𝑏ℤdelimited-⟨⟩𝛾G_{K}^{ab}=\mathbb{Z}=\langle\gamma\rangle into G​L2​(ℤ​[t,t−1])𝐺subscript𝐿2ℤ𝑡superscript𝑡1GL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}[t,t^{-1}]) by the rule

γ⟼(t00t).⟼𝛾𝑡00𝑡\gamma\longmapsto\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}t&0\\ 0&t\\ \end{array}\right).

Since the image of γ𝛾\gamma is a scalar matrix, i.e. lies in the center of G​L2​(ℤ​[t,t−1])𝐺subscript𝐿2ℤ𝑡superscript𝑡1GL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}[t,t^{-1}]), we constructed a faithful linear representation of GK⊗GKtensor-productsubscript𝐺𝐾subscript𝐺𝐾G_{K}\otimes G_{K}. ∎

Example 4.3.

1) The braid group B3subscript𝐵3B_{3} on 3 strings has presentation

B3=⟨σ1,σ2|​|σ1​σ2​σ1=σ2​σ1​σ2⟩.subscript𝐵3brasubscript𝜎1subscript𝜎2ketsubscript𝜎1subscript𝜎2subscript𝜎1subscript𝜎2subscript𝜎1subscript𝜎2B_{3}=\langle\sigma_{1},\sigma_{2}~{}||~{}\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}\sigma_{1}=\sigma_{2}\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}\rangle.

and is the group of trefoil knot. The commutator subgroup B3′superscriptsubscript𝐵3′B_{3}^{\prime} is a free group of rank 2. Hence the tensor square B3⊗B3=ℤ×F2tensor-productsubscript𝐵3subscript𝐵3ℤsubscript𝐹2B_{3}\otimes B_{3}=\mathbb{Z}\times F_{2} has a faithful linear representation into G​L2​(ℤ​[t,t−1])𝐺subscript𝐿2ℤ𝑡superscript𝑡1GL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}[t,t^{-1}]).

2) It is known that the group of the figure eight knot has a presentation

G=⟨x,y|​|y​x−1​y​x​y−1=x−1​y​x​y−1​x⟩𝐺bra𝑥𝑦ket𝑦superscript𝑥1𝑦𝑥superscript𝑦1superscript𝑥1𝑦𝑥superscript𝑦1𝑥G=\langle x,y~{}||~{}yx^{-1}yxy^{-1}=x^{-1}yxy^{-1}x\rangle

and is a fibered knot. Hence the tensor square G⊗G=ℤ×G′tensor-product𝐺𝐺ℤsuperscript𝐺′G\otimes G=\mathbb{Z}\times G^{\prime} has a faithful linear representation into G​L2​(ℤ​[t,t−1])𝐺subscript𝐿2ℤ𝑡superscript𝑡1GL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}[t,t^{-1}]).

In the first example we shown that B3⊗B3=ℤ×F2tensor-productsubscript𝐵3subscript𝐵3ℤsubscript𝐹2B_{3}\otimes B_{3}=\mathbb{Z}\times F_{2}. On the other side B3subscript𝐵3B_{3} contains the pure braid group P3subscript𝑃3P_{3}, which is normal in B3subscript𝐵3B_{3}, has index 6 and is the direct product of the center, which is isomorphic to ℤℤ\mathbb{Z}, and a free group of rank 2. Hence, B3⊗B3tensor-productsubscript𝐵3subscript𝐵3B_{3}\otimes B_{3} is isomorphic to P3subscript𝑃3P_{3} and we proved

Proposition 4.4.

There is a non-trivial non-abelian group G𝐺G such that the tensor square G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G is isomorphic to a proper subgroup of G𝐺G.

Question 2.

1) Is it true that Bn⊗Bntensor-productsubscript𝐵𝑛subscript𝐵𝑛B_{n}\otimes B_{n}, n>3𝑛3n>3, is linear?

2) Is it true that for arbitrary tame knot K𝐾K the group G​(K)⊗G​(K)tensor-product𝐺𝐾𝐺𝐾G(K)\otimes G(K) is linear?

5. On the linearity of the Peiffer product

Recall the definition of the Peiffer product. Given G𝐺G and H𝐻H acting compatibly on each other, in [21] the Peiffer product G⋈H⋈𝐺𝐻G\bowtie H was defined their as the quotient of the free product G∗H𝐺𝐻G*H by the normal closure K𝐾K of all elements of the form

h−1​g−1​h​gh​or​g−1​h−1​g​hgsuperscriptℎ1superscript𝑔1ℎsuperscript𝑔ℎorsuperscript𝑔1superscriptℎ1𝑔superscriptℎ𝑔h^{-1}g^{-1}hg^{h}~{}\mbox{or}~{}g^{-1}h^{-1}gh^{g}

where g∈G𝑔𝐺g\in G and h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in H. Whitehead [21] posed a question on the asphericity of subcomplexes of aspherical 2-complexes and reformulated it as part of the wider problem of finding conditions under which the groups G𝐺G and H𝐻H are embedded in G⋈H⋈𝐺𝐻G\bowtie H.

In [4] it was proved that if φ:G∗H→G⋈H:𝜑→𝐺𝐻𝐺⋈𝐻\varphi:G*H\to G\bowtie H, then modulo K=K​e​r​(φ)𝐾𝐾𝑒𝑟𝜑K=Ker(\varphi), h​g≡g​hgℎ𝑔𝑔superscriptℎ𝑔hg\equiv gh^{g}, so that every element of G⋈H⋈𝐺𝐻G\bowtie H can be written as φ​(g)​φ​(h)𝜑𝑔𝜑ℎ\varphi(g)\varphi(h) for suitable g𝑔g, hℎh. Denote φ​(g)​φ​(h)𝜑𝑔𝜑ℎ\varphi(g)\varphi(h) as ⟨g,h⟩𝑔ℎ\langle g,h\rangle. The relations

⟨g,h⟩​⟨g1,h1⟩=⟨g​g1,hg1​h1⟩=⟨g​g1h−1,h​h1⟩𝑔ℎsubscript𝑔1subscriptℎ1𝑔subscript𝑔1superscriptℎsubscript𝑔1subscriptℎ1𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑔1superscriptℎ1ℎsubscriptℎ1\langle g,h\rangle\langle g_{1},h_{1}\rangle=\langle gg_{1},h^{g_{1}}h_{1}\rangle=\langle gg_{1}^{h^{-1}},hh_{1}\rangle

are defining relations for G⋈H⋈𝐺𝐻G\bowtie H on the generators ⟨g,h⟩𝑔ℎ\langle g,h\rangle and so G⋈H⋈𝐺𝐻G\bowtie H is a homomorphic image of both the semidirect products G⋉Hleft-normal-factor-semidirect-product𝐺𝐻G\ltimes H and G⋊Hright-normal-factor-semidirect-product𝐺𝐻G\rtimes H. The group G⋈H⋈𝐺𝐻G\bowtie H is obtained from G⋉Hleft-normal-factor-semidirect-product𝐺𝐻G\ltimes H (or from G⋊Hright-normal-factor-semidirect-product𝐺𝐻G\rtimes H) by imposing the relations

(g−1​gh,1)=(1,h−g​h).superscript𝑔1superscript𝑔ℎ11superscriptℎ𝑔ℎ(g^{-1}g^{h},1)=(1,h^{-g}h).

If G𝐺G and H𝐻H act on one another trivially, then G⋈H⋈𝐺𝐻G\bowtie H is just the direct product G×H𝐺𝐻G\times H and K=G​□​H𝐾𝐺□𝐻K=G\square H, where G​□​H𝐺□𝐻G\square H is the Cartesian subgroup of G∗H𝐺𝐻G*H (the kernel of the canonical homomorphism G∗H⟶G×H⟶𝐺𝐻𝐺𝐻G*H\longrightarrow G\times H.

From [4, Proposition 2.1] follows

G⋈G≅Ga​b×Ga​b.⋈𝐺𝐺superscript𝐺𝑎𝑏superscript𝐺𝑎𝑏G\bowtie G\cong G^{ab}\times G^{ab}.

Using this isomorphism one can prove

Proposition 5.1.

Let G𝐺G be a linear group and G𝐺G is finitely generated or G=G′𝐺superscript𝐺′G=G^{\prime}, then G⋈G⋈𝐺𝐺G\bowtie G is linear.

From this proposition it follows that if G=S​Ln​(ℚ)𝐺𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚG=SL_{n}(\mathbb{Q}), n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2, then G⋈G⋈𝐺𝐺G\bowtie G is linear. On the other side, we know that S​Ln​(ℚ)⊗S​Ln​(ℚ)tensor-product𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚ𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚSL_{n}(\mathbb{Q})\otimes SL_{n}(\mathbb{Q}) and S​Ln​(ℚ)∧S​Ln​(ℚ)𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚ𝑆subscript𝐿𝑛ℚSL_{n}(\mathbb{Q})\wedge SL_{n}(\mathbb{Q}) are not linear for n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3.

Note that this proposition is not true for arbitrary linear group G𝐺G since there are linear groups with nonlinear abelization.

6. Faithful linear representations

In the paper [2] it was proved:

1) If Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n} is the free group of rank n𝑛n, then

Fn⊗Fn≅ℤn​(n+1)/2×(Fn)′.tensor-productsubscript𝐹𝑛subscript𝐹𝑛superscriptℤ𝑛𝑛12superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛′F_{n}\otimes F_{n}\cong\mathbb{Z}^{n(n+1)/2}\times(F_{n})^{\prime}.

2) If Nn,c=Fn/γc​Fnsubscript𝑁𝑛𝑐subscript𝐹𝑛subscript𝛾𝑐subscript𝐹𝑛N_{n,c}=F_{n}/\gamma_{c}F_{n} is the free nilpotent group of rank n>1𝑛1n>1 and class c≥1𝑐1c\geq 1, then

Nn,c⊗Nn,c≅ℤn​(n+1)/2×(Nn,c+1)′.tensor-productsubscript𝑁𝑛𝑐subscript𝑁𝑛𝑐superscriptℤ𝑛𝑛12superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑛𝑐1′N_{n,c}\otimes N_{n,c}\cong\mathbb{Z}^{n(n+1)/2}\times(N_{n,c+1})^{\prime}.
Proposition 6.1.

Let G𝐺G be a free countable group. Then the exterior square G∧G𝐺𝐺G\wedge G has a faithful representation into S​L2​(ℤ)𝑆subscript𝐿2ℤSL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}) and the tensor square G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G has a faithful representation into G​L2​(ℂ)𝐺subscript𝐿2ℂGL_{2}(\mathbb{C}).

Proof.

As was proven in [9], for the free group G𝐺G there are isomorphisms

G∧G≅G′,G⊗G≅Γ​(Ga​b)×G′.formulae-sequence𝐺𝐺superscript𝐺′tensor-product𝐺𝐺Γsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏superscript𝐺′G\wedge G\cong G^{\prime},~{}~{}~{}G\otimes G\cong\Gamma(G^{ab})\times G^{\prime}.

Since G𝐺G is free, its commutator subgroup G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} is free. Hence, by the Sanov result [11, Chapter 5] there is a faithful representation of G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} into S​L2​(ℤ)𝑆subscript𝐿2ℤSL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}) and the first part of the proposition holds.

Further, Γ​(Ga​b)Γsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏\Gamma(G^{ab}) is a free abelian group. Let aksubscript𝑎𝑘a_{k}, k∈I𝑘𝐼k\in I be its free generators. Take transcendental elements tksubscript𝑡𝑘t_{k}, k∈I𝑘𝐼k\in I in the field ℂℂ\mathbb{C}, which are algebraically independent over ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}. Then the matrix group

T=⟨(tk00tk)∥k∈I⟩𝑇inner-productsubscript𝑡𝑘00subscript𝑡𝑘𝑘𝐼T=\left\langle\,\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}t_{k}&0\\ 0&t_{k}\\ \end{array}\right)\,\,\|\,\,k\in I\,\right\rangle

is isomorphic to the group Γ​(Ga​b)Γsuperscript𝐺𝑎𝑏\Gamma(G^{ab}). If φ:G′⟶G​L2​(ℤ):𝜑⟶superscript𝐺′𝐺subscript𝐿2ℤ\varphi:G^{\prime}\longrightarrow GL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}) is an embedding, then

⟨φ​G′,T⟩≅φ​G′×T.𝜑superscript𝐺′𝑇𝜑superscript𝐺′𝑇\left\langle\,\varphi G^{\prime},\,T\,\right\rangle\cong\varphi G^{\prime}\times T.

Hence, the group G⊗Gtensor-product𝐺𝐺G\otimes G has a faithful representation in the matrix group over the ring ℤ​[tk±1,k∈I]ℤdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘plus-or-minus1𝑘𝐼\mathbb{Z}[t_{k}^{\pm 1},k\in I].

If G=F∞𝐺subscript𝐹G=F_{\infty} is countably generated then it has a faithful representation into S​L2​(ℤ)𝑆subscript𝐿2ℤSL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}). To prove that Γ​(F∞a​b)Γsuperscriptsubscript𝐹𝑎𝑏\Gamma(F_{\infty}^{ab}) is linear we use the following property

Γ​(F∞a​b)=Γ​(limFna​b)=lim(Γ​Fna​b).Γsuperscriptsubscript𝐹𝑎𝑏Γsuperscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛𝑎𝑏Γsuperscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛𝑎𝑏\Gamma(F_{\infty}^{ab})=\Gamma(\lim F_{n}^{ab})=\lim(\Gamma F_{n}^{ab}).

∎

For the finitely generated free groups from this theorem follows

Corollary 6.2.

The tensor square Fn⊗Fntensor-productsubscript𝐹𝑛subscript𝐹𝑛F_{n}\otimes F_{n} has a faithful representation into G​L2​(ℤ​[t1±1,…,tm±1])𝐺subscript𝐿2ℤsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1plus-or-minus1…superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑚plus-or-minus1GL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}[t_{1}^{\pm 1},\ldots,t_{m}^{\pm 1}]), where m=n​(n+1)2𝑚𝑛𝑛12m=\frac{n(n+1)}{2}.

For the free nilpotent groups we can prove

Proposition 6.3.

There is a faithful representation

As Romanovskii proved [16] the map, defined on xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is a faithful representation of Nn,c+1subscript𝑁𝑛𝑐1N_{n,c+1} into U​Tc+2​(ℂ)𝑈subscript𝑇𝑐2ℂUT_{c+2}(\mathbb{C}). Hence we have a faithful representation of ℤn​(n+1)/2×Nn,c+1superscriptℤ𝑛𝑛12subscript𝑁𝑛𝑐1\mathbb{Z}^{n(n+1)/2}\times N_{n,c+1} into Tc+2​(ℂ)subscript𝑇𝑐2ℂT_{c+2}(\mathbb{C}). Since ℤn​(n+1)/2×(Nn,c+1)′superscriptℤ𝑛𝑛12superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑛𝑐1′\mathbb{Z}^{n(n+1)/2}\times(N_{n,c+1})^{\prime} is a subgroup of ℤn​(n+1)/2×Nn,c+1superscriptℤ𝑛𝑛12subscript𝑁𝑛𝑐1\mathbb{Z}^{n(n+1)/2}\times N_{n,c+1}, we have the needed representation. ∎
